rev.comment: /* Name of the plaza */ health department inspected and approved camp-- convert asserted fact to attributed statement
rev.diff:
Line 21: Line 21:
In 1998, the [[Oakland#Government|Oakland City Council]] renamed City Hall Plaza as "Frank H. Ogawa Plaza"<ref name=Historytimeline>{{cite web|url= http://oaklandnet.com/celebrate/Historytimeline.htm |title= Oakland History Timeline |publisher= City of Oakland, Oakland History Room of the Oakland Public Library |accessdate= 2011-11-08 |quote= 1998 Named in honor of late Oakland City Councilmember Frank H. Ogawa, City Hall Plaza re-opens after a $124 million rebuilding.}}</ref> in honor of [[Frank H. Ogawa]]. Ogawa was a [[Civil and political rights|civil rights]] leader<ref name=eshoo>{{cite web |url= http://www.gpo.gov/fdsys/pkg/CREC-1994-07-21/html/CREC-1994-07-21-pt1-PgE6.htm |title= TRIBUTE TO FRANK H. OGAWA |first= Anna |last= Eshoo |authorlink= Anna Eshoo |date= 1994-07-21 |work= [[Congressional Record]] Volume 140, Number 96 |publisher= [[United States House of Representatives]] |archiveurl= |archivedate= |deadurl= |accessdate= 2011-10-31 |quote= Mr. Speaker, I rise today to pay tribute to Frank Ogawa--a dedicated public servant, outstanding civil rights leader, and loving husband and father--who passed away earlier this month in Oakland, California.}}</ref> and the first [[Japanese American]] to serve on the Oakland City Council<ref name=Historytimeline/> in which he served from 1966 until his death in 1994.<ref name=statue>{{cite video |last1= Allen |first1= Annalee |last2= Lee |first2= Sam |title= Oakland City Center: Frank H. Ogawa Statue (video) |url= http://video.ezinemark.com/exploring-the-oakland-city-center-oakland-city-center-frank-h.-ogawa-statue-44bf4d7e134.html |publisher= EzineMark.com |archiveurl= |archivedate= |accessdate= 2011-10-31}}</ref> The plaza displays a bronze bust of Ogawa.
In 1998, the [[Oakland#Government|Oakland City Council]] renamed City Hall Plaza as "Frank H. Ogawa Plaza"<ref name=Historytimeline>{{cite web|url= http://oaklandnet.com/celebrate/Historytimeline.htm |title= Oakland History Timeline |publisher= City of Oakland, Oakland History Room of the Oakland Public Library |accessdate= 2011-11-08 |quote= 1998 Named in honor of late Oakland City Councilmember Frank H. Ogawa, City Hall Plaza re-opens after a $124 million rebuilding.}}</ref> in honor of [[Frank H. Ogawa]]. Ogawa was a [[Civil and political rights|civil rights]] leader<ref name=eshoo>{{cite web |url= http://www.gpo.gov/fdsys/pkg/CREC-1994-07-21/html/CREC-1994-07-21-pt1-PgE6.htm |title= TRIBUTE TO FRANK H. OGAWA |first= Anna |last= Eshoo |authorlink= Anna Eshoo |date= 1994-07-21 |work= [[Congressional Record]] Volume 140, Number 96 |publisher= [[United States House of Representatives]] |archiveurl= |archivedate= |deadurl= |accessdate= 2011-10-31 |quote= Mr. Speaker, I rise today to pay tribute to Frank Ogawa--a dedicated public servant, outstanding civil rights leader, and loving husband and father--who passed away earlier this month in Oakland, California.}}</ref> and the first [[Japanese American]] to serve on the Oakland City Council<ref name=Historytimeline/> in which he served from 1966 until his death in 1994.<ref name=statue>{{cite video |last1= Allen |first1= Annalee |last2= Lee |first2= Sam |title= Oakland City Center: Frank H. Ogawa Statue (video) |url= http://video.ezinemark.com/exploring-the-oakland-city-center-oakland-city-center-frank-h.-ogawa-statue-44bf4d7e134.html |publisher= EzineMark.com |archiveurl= |archivedate= |accessdate= 2011-10-31}}</ref> The plaza displays a bronze bust of Ogawa.
â
[[Occupy Oakland]] protesters began squatting in the plaza on October 10, 2011. Their presence brought a pre-existing rat problem out of control, and caused concerns over "illegal drug and alcohol abuse, fighting, and sexual harassment in and around the camp". The grass lawn of the plaza was destroyed.<ref>http://www.mercurynews.com/bay-area-news/ci_19139574</ref> The protestors symbolically renamed
+
Members of [[Occupy Oakland]] use Ogawa plaza as a main protest encampment starting on on October 10, 2011. Their presence has been criticize for potential health and safety concerns.<ref>http://www.mercurynews.com/bay-area-news/ci_19139574</ref> The protestors symbolically renamed
Frank H. Ogawa Plaza as "Oscar Grant Plaza". [[Oscar Grant]] was a young African American man who was shot in the back by a white [[Bay Area Rapid Transit]] police officer in 2009.<ref>{{cite web
Frank H. Ogawa Plaza as "Oscar Grant Plaza". [[Oscar Grant]] was a young African American man who was shot in the back by a white [[Bay Area Rapid Transit]] police officer in 2009.<ref>{{cite web
| url=http://blog.sfgate.com/abraham/2011/10/30/occupy-oakland-the-oscar-grant-frank-ogawa-plaza-issue/ | title=Occupy Oakland: The Oscar Grant / Frank Ogawa Plaza Issue | first=Zennie | last=Abraham | date= 2011-10-30 | publisher=[[San Francisco Chronicle]] | accessdate= 2011-11-11 | archiveurl= http://www.webcitation.org/6380s6A8K | archivedate= 2011-11-11 | deadurl= no}}</ref>
| url=http://blog.sfgate.com/abraham/2011/10/30/occupy-oakland-the-oscar-grant-frank-ogawa-plaza-issue/ | title=Occupy Oakland: The Oscar Grant / Frank Ogawa Plaza Issue | first=Zennie | last=Abraham | date= 2011-10-30 | publisher=[[San Francisco Chronicle]] | accessdate= 2011-11-11 | archiveurl= http://www.webcitation.org/6380s6A8K | archivedate= 2011-11-11 | deadurl= no}}</ref>
